A pseudo-immersive virtual environment—a framework for modelling sheet deformation

A pseudo-immersive virtual environment—a framework for modelling sheet deformation

  • B. S. Mahal1,
  • D. E. R. Clark2 &
  • J. E. L. Simmons1 

Virtual Reality volume 8, pages1–16(2004)Cite this article

  • 84 Accesses

  • Metrics details

Abstract

This paper presents a real-time, computationally inexpensive environment for accurate simulations of sheet materials on a personal computer. The approach described differs from other techniques through its novel use of multilayer sheet structures. The ultimate aim is to incorporate into the environment the capacity of simulating a range of temperatures. A pseudo-immersive “Window on World” (WoW) environment is used to handle the implementation of the real-time, aesthetically accurate deformation algorithm (MaSSE-Mass-Spring Simulation Engine). The motion of the sheet is controlled by simulated gravity and through its interaction with objects that have been inserted into a virtual room. In addition, the WoW interface is used to adjust environmental parameters dynamically and adjust the scene viewing perspective. An obvious use of the environment is centred on mechanical engineering-based real-time simulations of heat-sensitive sheet materials. This would allow for a wide range of applications in virtual manufacturing including the clothing industry and hostile environments.

Introduction

The aim of this paper is to describe a computer-based geometric model that is capable of simulating the complex mechanical behaviour of thermoplastic sheet materials over an appropriate temperature range. It is anticipated that the resultant physics/dynamics engine of this research may be adopted as an autonomous engineering package within a wide range of virtual reality applications. The interface allows for the dynamic adjustment of relevant simulation parameters and provides mouse functionality to allow the user to ‘fly’ around the setting and view the deformation process from any viewing perspective within the environment through the use of a rotation, pan and zoom facility. This ability allows the user to view the sheet model from any three-dimensional perspective, thereby eliminating the need for a specialised environment [1].

Traditionally, continuously deformable models have been represented using control points that are arranged in a grid format. The interaction properties between these points are controlled via a series of interconnections. These are used in physically based modelling to represent environmental effects within a simulation. Effects vary from the transfer of forces from one control point (or node) to its neighbouring nodes, to representing real-world forces such as friction and energy damping, which affect any object placed in an uncontrolled environment.

Mass-spring-based systems represent one such example of utilising control points and have been shown to work effectively within graphics-based animation and simulation [2], portraying fast and aesthetically accurate behaviour of cloth [3, 4, 5] and other geometric objects [6]. Research to date in sheet simulation has been restricted to simulation of cloth-based applications [3, 7, 8, 9, 10]. The approach described in this paper differs from other techniques through its novel use of multi-layer sheet structures. This structure has the potential to produce highly accurate results without the required high levels of computation demanded by finite-element methods [11, 12].

A second important research objective is the production of an aesthetically accurate simulation of thermo-sensitive sheet behaviour in an environment that can be set at various temperatures. To date, attempts at modelling heat within virtual environments have remained within the realm of haptic interfaces [13], animation of turbulent hot gases[14, 15] and simulations of fire in virtual buildings [16]. These immersive simulations have tended to concentrate upon the representation and behaviour of fire within a confined space, rather than the effects of heat per se upon objects within an environment.

The pseudo-immersive virtual environment

In this section, we describe the construction of a pseudo-immersive three-dimensional computer-generated virtual environment. This setting underpins the applications and the sheet simulation experimentation work. These applications are covered in Sects. 5–9, with descriptions and results of experimental work being discussed in Sect. 10.

The pseudo-immersive virtual environment was created as a basis for real-time sheet simulation. The principal feature is the ability to view the animation from any desired three-dimensional perspective whilst retaining the ability to adapt simulation parameters dynamically. The system follows an intuitive design that eliminates the need for complex software interfaces or expensive specialist hardware [17].

The adoption of a pseudo-immersive WoW interface permits the simulation to operate on a wide range of PC platforms without the need for dedicated hardware whilst retaining a highly effective degree of user interaction within the system.

The system is comprised of two distinct components. The interface environment that is used to control the view and behaviour of the simulation (through use of the on-line dialog boxes and the simulation display window) and the kernel that links into the designated MaSSE engine and collision detection routines to perform the study of sheet behaviour.

The pseudo-immersive environment is constructed using Visual C++ combined with the Microsoft Foundation Classes (MFC) and the Open Graphics Library, which in turn uses the Graphics Library Utility Toolkit (GLuT) and the Graphics Library Utility Interface (GLuI). The system may operate on any 32-bit Microsoft Windows platform with a practical minimum specification of a 400-MHz Pentium II processor.

The World on Window interface

The Window on World (WoW) structure is comprised of several distinctive parts. The primary interface is the simulation window (Fig. 1), which displays the simulation room environment. The room in its simplest form consists of a floor and back wall and is subject to natural forces such as simulated gravity. During the simulation initialisation stage the user selects and uploads a sheet, polyhedra and, if required, room heater into the scene. Once running, the sheet will be viewed falling from its initial position before colliding with the polyhedra. The capability exists to vary a number of model parameters as the program proceeds. This is achieved either through the simulation window menu system (selected by right-clicking on the simulation window) or through the use of the dynamic dialog boxes.

The dynamic dialog boxes of the WoW interface (Fig. 2) enhance the capability of the software to be adapted to specified criteria. The interface has five dynamic dialog boxes that allow the simulation parameters to be adjusted in real time. These boxes consist of parameters for:

The mouse interface

This displays and controls the display mode of the mouse within the simulation window (i.e. rotation, pan, zoom or none).

Sheet display properties

These control how much of the sheet is displayed (e.g. springs, masses or simply the sheet layer itself), whether the top or bottom layer of the sheet is displayed and whether the NURBS functionality is active.

Internal sheet properties

This displays and allows the user to adjust the internal damping coefficient of the sheet.

Sheet calculation properties

This menu determines the computation engine for modelling the sheet behaviour (i.e. Analytical, first-order Euler-Cromer, second-order Euler-Richardson or fourth-order Runge-Kutta), and environmental parameters such as air damping, timestep and friction.

Heat simulation properties

This controls the temperature of any heat source (if present) and, if active, the ambient room temperature for the over-heat facility.

The interface viewing environment is controlled by the use of a conventional two-dimensional PC-based two-button mouse. Rotation (or flight) around the environment is initiated by the user through depression of the left mouse button, combined with simultaneous movement of the mouse in the direction from which the user would like the new camera perspective. Alternative mouse-based view-angle functionality includes viewpoint panning and the ability to zoom in and out of the scene.

Use of the rotation facility is demonstrated in Fig. 3, where the movement of the mouse (with left mouse button depressed) is highlighted by the blue arrow, resulting in the new viewing angle illustrated in the next frame.

Vertical mouse movements result in a change in altitude while a horizontal movement results in a variation of the lateral view of the scene.

This rotational facility is an integral component of the WoW environment, allowing the user to view the sheet deformation even when obscured by the polyhedra objects. To aid the viewing process, the back wall and floor act as one-way mirrors, thus providing a basis for the scene. This allows the user to view the sheet and polyhedra when the viewpoint is behind or below the back wall or floor.

Figure 4 highlights the effect of the use of the pan facility, which is particularly useful when viewing the behaviour of a sheet, or partial sheet that is off-centre or that, as a result of a collision, has become offset from the centre of the environment. In the following diagram, the movement of the depressed mouse is once more indicated by the blue arrows (vectors) with the horizontal/vertical direction and length of the movement forming a corresponding change in the scene view.

The capability of the environment to zoom in and out of specific sections of the sheet allows the user to focus on specific areas of the sheet as it encounters deformation from collision with a polyhedron. The facility operates by the horizontal movement of the mouse (Fig. 5), with a left movement resulting in the environment zooming out, to gain an overview of the complete environment. A movement towards the right of the screen operates the zoom-in facility that provides a close-up of any particular element of the simulation.

Collision detection

Standard collision detection algorithms result in an explosive growth of collision tests as the number of objects on the screen increase [18, 19, 20]. Hence, for the current environment, two approaches were adopted in order to provide the fastest and most efficient solution.

The first level of detection utilises game rules to imply that a specific sprite need not be collision tested against other sprites. Sprites are objects on the screen that may be animated or moving. In the current system these rules simply state that static sprites are not collision tested against other static sprites. As with many collision detection routines, the focus of interest is the sprites within the screen space.

The sector method works by dividing the screen (or simulation view) into a grid of sectors. The algorithm then determines which sector each sprite is located in according to its screen position. A standard collision test is then made against any sprites that are within the same sector. Inefficiencies occur when a sprite lies on the boundary of two or more sectors, resulting in collision tests having to be performed between the sprite in question and every other sprite positioned within any of the bordering sectors.

The second level of collision detection works by determining the equation of the plane for any surfaces in the simulation. The system then analyses the positions of all the sheet control points and, using the point-plane test, determines whether they lie above or below each of the simulation planes.

The test works whereby P=(x,y,z) = Point, N=(A,B,C) = normal to the collision plane

$$Ax + By + Cz + D = 0\;\;{\text{or}}\;\;N \cdot P + D = 0$$
$$ \begin{aligned} & f{\left( P \right)} = 0, \\ & {\text{if}}\;f{\left( P \right)} > 0,\;{\text{then}}\;{\text{the}}\;{\text{point}}\;{\text{P}}\;{\text{is}}\;{\text{above}}\;{\text{the}}\;{\text{plane}}{\text{.}} \\ \end{aligned} $$

Mass-spring systems

Each mass instance (or sheet control point), when acting as an individual particle in free space, obeys Newton’s second law:

$$ ma = {\user2{f}} $$

where the mass (m) of the particle multiplied by the particle’s acceleration (a) is equal to the sum of the forces (f) acting upon it. Based upon this expression, a position and velocity matrix (or vector) is used to determine force and acceleration. In a free-space system of n independent particles, the force calculation per control point is of order O(n). When this is adapted to take into account interactions with other particles, it results in a force calculation of order O(n 2). In conventional particle systems, this figure would be reduced to take into account the effects of only those particles that are close to it.

Particle-spring systems were selected as the chosen simulation technique for the system because they cater efficiently to the effects of internal forces placed on particles by nearby surrounding particles. This results in a system that behaves with greater realism when encountering external forces upon individual (or groups of) particles. These forces may include gravity, impulses due to collisions with other objects, or user manipulation. The adoption of a mesh structure uses each control point as a vertex for a rectangular mesh, which changes over time due to the influence of external forces, and those induced by neighbouring particles.

Figure 6 illustrates a typical arrangement of a mesh-based sheet particle-spring structure. This changes its configuration over time due to external influences such as gravity [5, 9], manipulation by virtual actors [3, 7, 8] or wind. Any successful simulation will have to consider external and internal sheet forces. If P ij is the location of the mass in row i, column j of the mesh, the force calculation for P ij will have to consider the forces between P ij and the four adjacent locations P i+1,j , P i−1,j , P i,j+1, and P i,j−1.

For a breakdown of calculations, consider two adjacent masses connected by a spring (Fig. 7), with f denoting the force acting upon particle p from particle q and s representing the spring’s undisplaced (or rest) length.

When stretched, the spring is subject to Hooke’s law (Eq. 1) and will generate a force that will act in the direction d=p–q, along the direct line between the particles.

The symbol k s represents the spring constant (or stiffness value) and describes the situation as the particles move further apart; then a greater force will be applied to bring the particles back together again:

$$ {\user2{f}} = - k_{s} {\left( {{\left| {\user2{d}} \right|} - s} \right)}\frac{{\user2{d}}} {{{\left| {\user2{d}} \right|}}}. $$
(1)

When implemented in this simplistic form, the mass-spring system will start to oscillate and, if left undisturbed, continue forever. To cater to this eventuality, a level of damping must be retrofitted into Hooke’s original equation (which has no built-in friction coefficient). This results in the equation

$$ {\user2{f}} = - {\left( {k_{s} {\left( {{\left| {\user2{d}} \right|} - s} \right)} + k_{d} \frac{{{\user2{\ifmmode\expandafter\dot\else\expandafter\.\fi{d}}} \cdot {\user2{d}}}} {{{\left| {\user2{d}} \right|}}}} \right)}\frac{{\user2{d}}} {{{\left| {\user2{d}} \right|}}}, $$

where k d is the damping constant and

$$ {\user2{\ifmmode\expandafter\dot\else\expandafter\.\fi{d}}} = {\user2{\ifmmode\expandafter\dot\else\expandafter\.\fi{p}}} - {\user2{\ifmmode\expandafter\dot\else\expandafter\.\fi{q}}} = {\user2{v}}_{p} - {\user2{v}}_{q}. $$

The effect of this is to generate a proportional force that acts in the same direction as the spring force.

Likewise, when dealing with elastic materials, if two masses are forced together so that the distance between them is less than the undisplaced length of the spring joining them, then a repulsive force is generated.

At any one timestep, several parameters are invoked to describe the behaviour of each control point within free space. These parameters are mapped using three-dimensional vectors. These parameters include the mass’s current location, the directions of any applied forces, the current point velocity and acceleration.

A value for the actual mass of the control point is also maintained. The mass instances are interconnected through a network of spring systems that also have properties that are used to describe the behaviour of the spring during the simulation.

Spring data include information about the relative position of the spring within the sheet model (using pointers to its interconnected masses), the degree of axial spring stiffness and its undisplaced length. All three of these properties come together during the simulation to determine the behaviour of the object being modelled.

To enhance the visual feel of the sheet as it drapes over polyhedra within the environment, the use of non-uniform rational B-spline (NURBS) surfaces are incorporated into our model. NURBS surfaces are used in numerous applications to produce fast, smooth surfaces from disparate data [21].

The MaSSE engine

The mass-spring simulation engine is in fact three derivatives of a ‘core’ spring calculation engine structure, with each arrangement being adapted to suit its respective ordinary differential equation (ODE) engine method. Regardless of the depth of ODE calculation, the core approach is used to calculate all dynamics-based equations in the deformation environment. This design of the engine is easily extendable so that in future the MaSSE system will cater to a diversity of additional shape simulations such as non-lamina models [6].

The foremost and simplest variation (Fig. 8) was designed for first-order calculations which, due to its simple formatting, offered the fastest and most computationally cost-effective system.

The second engine permutation uses the mid-point approach, which requires an additional level of calculation for the (intermediate) stage between timesteps. However, the overhead of this increased accuracy has been minimised in the engine design (Fig. 9) by means of the software’s capability of calculating the mid-step as an extension of the full-step computation without the need to retain any additional data over and above what is required for the first-order system.

The final evolution of the MaSSE system (Fig. 10) was developed to perform fourth-order calculations within the environment. Although computationally expensive, this approach is regarded as the common benchmark for most dynamics-based calculation work. Due to its complex nature, instead of dealing with each of the four equation levels individually for each mass, the system must predict the forces, velocities, accelerations and positions for the entire sheet for each level, prior to calculating the next stage of the Runge-Kutta differential equation. As one would expect, this not only produces a considerable computational burden on the processing hardware but, more significantly, requires the storage of vast amounts of data for the entire sheet for every timestep.

A simple generalised, single-degree-of-freedom model is used to represent frictional forces acting upon the sheet within the environment (Fig. 11).

This method is generally considered to be the established approach to damping in spring-based systems [22].

Bending moment representation

One novel aspect of the MaSSE system compared to traditional mass-spring systems is the way it deals with bending moment force.

Traditional mass-spring research tends to employ 2D structures (such as those illustrated in Fig. 12) with complex rotational stiffness calculations to simulate bending moment [23]. This is achieved by implanting each mass with a horizontal axis component that identifies a horizontal plane for the mass. Then, through a complex set of calculations performed in every timestep, a comparison is made between the angles of the two opposite-end springs that are connected to each mass. If their angle value (indicated by Θ in Fig. 12) is greater than arbitrary preset values, then restrictions are placed on the angle of the second spring to ensure that Θ remains at the preset rotational value. These restrictions are used to prevent the masses from falling vertically (like a chain) and instead result in the formation of a curve, thus representing the effects of a bending moment.

As a breakaway from the employment of complex resource intensive rotational stiffness calculations during sheet bending [23, 24, 25, 26], three-dimensional structures are employed to cater to the moment force. Together with experimentation in our various sheet structures these lead to an efficient alternative to current approaches [5].

In essence, the MaSSE approach (Fig. 13) uses a simpler piece of code to calculate sheet behaviour that is executed many times, rather than using a complex (rotational stiffness) algorithm that is involved fewer times per frame. This way, through careful optimisation of the system, it is anticipated that significant improvements in sheet simulation will be achieved.

This system has several advantages over conventional 2D models such as those proposed by [26]. These include the fact that:

  1. 1.

    Any arrangement of sheet (or full three-dimensional) models may be developed and tested using the technique.

  2. 2.

    The structure follows a closer representation of real-world problems where any bending or deforming modelling represents ideas based upon three-dimensional laws and mathematical principles.

In this instance two classes of springs have been devised to differentiate between shear and bending moment force that are characterised by plane-level and inter-layer springs.

Heat simulation

One of the main objectives of the environment under discussion is the accurate real-time representation of heat upon the thermal-sensitive materials. To accommodate this, two schemas were devised and implanted into the environment. The facility caters to the simulation of heat deformation upon the sheet from a specific heat source and from the room temperature itself.

Initially, a value is given to the sheet material to present its thermal sensitivity, in addition to a value for the current room temperature. At present, assumptions are made that the room shall be set at an initial constant and equally dissipated temperature, with no allowances made for additional effects such as convection or radiation.

Heat source method

Once a heat source is activated and set to a specified temperature the exact distance from the centre point of the sheet surface to the heat source is calculated. This gap is calculated by determining the interval between the four corners of the sheet and then enumerating the length mid-way between these points to the epicentre of the virtual heat source. This provides a numerically efficient method of determining the distance of the sheet to the heat source without the need for constantly reacquiring the distance between the heat source and the centre of each sheet spring (Fig. 14).

The algorithm then determines the quantity of radiation intersecting the sheet (Fig. 15) based upon the angle of the sheet to the heat source face, which is then divided by the number of sheet masses.

A linear calculation is then performed on each spring, adjusting its stiffness based upon its current stiffness, the distance of its SCP to the heat source, the coefficient of heat sensitivity representing the sheet, and the heat being generated by heat source and the ambient temperature.

A second coefficient exists for the sheet that is used to represent the sensitivity of the sheet to heat conduction. This operates by determining the distance of each spring relative to the heat source and the centre point of the sheet. Should the spring distance be less than the distance from the sheet centre to the heat source, the spring stiffness is further weakened; otherwise the value is increased in proportion to the increased distance.

Oven heat method

In addition to the heater system, a simplified sheet melting algorithm was also devised that performs uniform deformation across the entire sheet surface. Known as the ‘oven heat facility’, the system weakens each of the individual spring stiffness values until (as in the heat source facility) a minimum spring stiffness value is reached.

Once more this weakening effect takes into account the ambient room temperature, the thermal sensitivity of the sheet material and the time the material is exposed to the increased level of heat.

Experimental results

The work presented in this paper was conducted on an Intel Pentium III 866-MHz computer, running Windows 2000 equipped with 256 MB RAM and a 32 MB TNT2 PCI graphics card.

During the course of experimental testing, a number of idiosyncratic traits among the calculation engines were uncovered that prevented a balanced comparison between the differential equation approaches being made. The experimental work highlighted how, for a given scene, each MaSSE engine required significantly modified sheet and simulation parameters in order to gain a realistic and stable animation.

A set of typical sheet parameters for each differential calculation approach is detailed in Table 1.

These results indicate that:

  1. 1.

    The Runge-Kutta fourth-order method proves a stable and realistic model with high levels of spring stiffness to retain the shape of the sheet under periods of high load or stress, with low levels of damping thus preventing the sheet from behaving in a numb or static style. This was not unexpected as the fourth-order Runge-Kutta approach has long been considered the benchmark for most applications requiring resolution through use of differential equations. The downside of this accuracy is the additional computational overhead that accompanies the technique, although it did prove to be less significant than expected. The drawback of this and the second-order method was that they did not cater sufficiently to weak-spring sheets as the additional movement of the springs during a collision, combined with their low levels of damping, often resulted in the sheet becoming unstable.

  2. 2.

    The second-order (Euler-Richardson) approach has proved to be the darling of all the techniques because of its flexible nature in terms of high spring stiffness, low damping and stable nature without the high levels of computational overhead associated with the fourth-order approach. Once again, the approach did not adapt well to weak-spring sheet systems, although this was not considered to be a major drawback.

  3. 3.

    The first-order (or Euler-Cromer) calculation required significant levels of damping with weak-spring stiffness values to prevent a build-up of energy into the sheet system. If not prevented, the sheet will eventually become unstable and explode.

  4. 4.

    The analytical engine behaves in a similar manner to the first-order calculation with the noticeable setback of being even more sensitive to simulation conditions. This too requires weak values for spring stiffness and even higher levels of damping to extract energy from the system when interacting with external forces. Perhaps its greatest drawback, though, is the need for even smaller timesteps, which significantly undermine any advantages over the Euler-Cromer approach.

Experimental work has concentrated on modelling the performance of the second-order Euler-Richardson system as a SLaMM sheet falls under the effects of gravity from a predetermined distance above a single or group of polyhedra (Fig. 16). The time is then measured from when the simulation is initiated to:

  1. 1.

    When the sheet collides with the first polyhedron (Fig. 17).

  2. 2.

    Collision occurs with the second polyhedron (Fig. 18).

  3. 3.

    The sheet slides down the length of the second polyderon (Fig. 19).

  4. 4.

    The simulation comes to rest on the floor as the damping coefficients take effect (Fig. 20).

Parameters for the simulation are detailed in Table 2, with the time results displayed in Fig. 21. Table 2 details the dimensions of the SLaMM sheets that were tested, with all sheets having the same dimensions within the room environment and the level of sheet detail (determined by the number of masses and springs) being varied.

The results graph in Fig. 21 highlights the significant changes in processing time with minor changes in the proportions of the sheet complexity. This additional level of processing is substantiated in Table 3, which reveals how the numbers of masses and springs required by each model grows exponentially as the model size is increased. Testing showed that a sheet with a size of 11 masses in the x-axis by 2 masses in the y-axis by 11 masses in the z-axis (or 11×2×11) appears to give the most realistic behaviour while retaining a realistic sense of real-time processing.

Once the system had matured to a suitable level of stability the next stage of progress was to provide the environment with an accurate level of realism. To achieve this a method of real-world calibration was required, one that would provide a template for the behaviour of the virtual sheet as it fell onto the polyhedron. Figure 22 demonstrates an example of a typical sheet falling under the effects of gravity (photos A and B), colliding with the polyhedra (photo C), and settling over the object (photos D and E) before coming to a resting position (photo F).

In total, four sheets of different material were used. Two sheets were different grades of PVC, and the other two sheets were different thicknesses of Styrine (0.25 mm and 0.5 mm). These were filmed, at room temperature, falling onto five different polyhedra structures: a triangular edge shape (Fig. 22), a cube, an upright cylinder, a hemisphere and a horizontally lying hemicylinder.

Once the room temperature experiments were completed the same process was repeated, although on this occasion the polyhedra were heated. The sheets were then filmed not only falling but also melting onto the shapes.

Discussion and future development

This paper has reported on the development of a functional pseudo-immersive environment allowing three-dimensional structures and polyhedra to be dynamically installed at system run-time. Due to their exponential complexity, sheet structures created by a model-generation application allow the object to be given a variety of initial properties. At present only laminate deformable structures have been tested, although the facility does exist with the model-generation application to test simple-shaped three-dimensional deformable cubes. The environment performs well in our ‘falling’ sheet scenarios, producing simulations with a highly satisfactory level of realism in real time using modest computing facilities. Preliminary results of the system described in this paper have so far proven to be very encouraging, with all indications showing that the underlying aim is achieved. The MaSSE systems offer significant potential for use in virtual manufacturing and artificial scenarios set in hazardous environments that contain objects that are required to deform due to either collision or the effects of heat.

It is clear that a number of areas require additional enhancements in order to enable the system to be fully realistic.

  1. 1.

    A testing strategy will be implemented to evaluate the effectiveness of each of the MaSSE calculation engines in relation to timestep, stability and realism with real-world experimental studies. This will compare and contrast our simulated models to real-world thermoplastic sheets.

  2. 2.

    Further experimentation with non-laminate structures is required to test the suitability of the MaSSE engine as a generic mass-spring computational engine.

  3. 3.

    Optimisation of the MaSSE engine to cater to larger and more complex models while retaining its need for only modest computing facilities in its real-time performance.
